solution.text:
This can be done in two ways
One way is to find the position of the last term that is _{{j+(m-1)*k}}_
so, \(_{{j+(m-1)*k}}_=a_1+(n-1)*d\)
\(_{{j+(m-1)*k}}_=_{j}_+(n-1)*(a_2-a_1)\)
\(_{{j+(m-1)*k}}_=_{j}_+(n-1)*_{k}_\)
\(n=_{m}_\)
let us first find the position(t) of the given no. _{{j+(m-1)*k-(l-1)*(k)}}_ from the start.
therefore, \(t=(_{{j+(m-1)*k-(l-1)*(k)}}_-a_1)/d\,+\,1\)
\(t=_{{m-l}}_\)
Now position from the Last(p)= n-t
Hence,we get \(p=_{m}_-_{{m-l}}_\)
The value of p is \(_{l}_\)
the second way to solve this to by assuming the last term as the first
so, say \(b_1=_{{j+(m-1)*k}}_\)
and now new \(d' = -(a_2-a_1)=-_{k}_\)
\(b_p=b_1+(p-1)*d'\)
\(_{{j+(m-1)*k-(l-1)*(k)}}_=_{{j+(m-1)*k}}_+(p-1)*(-_{k}_)\)
we get \(p=_{l}_\)

content.text:
_{{j+(m-1)*k-(l-1)*(k)}}_ is the pth term from the last of an AP \(_{j}_,_{{j+k}}_,_{{j+(2*k)}}_,......._{{j+(m-1)*k}}_\)
find the value of P?
